description: For whatever reason, this comes pre-loaded with uBlock Origin. It's easy enough to remove, but it doesn't generally come baked in. Other than that, it seems to be LibreWolf in all it's glory.

As of last few days, this browser no longer works in a stable fashion due to a SIGSEGV error, with very frequent crashes. I am unable to report this with the bug reporter in my OS due to "low informational value".

I'm on Fedora 40 KDE with up-to-date Nvidia drivers(555.58.02 at the time of review) with an RTX 3070 as my GPU. This is the closest I can get for the time being to make this error known to the developers/maintainers of this flatpak.

The error was specifically 
"Librewolf killed by SIGSEGV - org.freedesktop.GnomeAbrt"
Great alternative to arkenfox! Very simple to use, easy to add cookie exceptions. (App's logo could really benefit from a redesign though)
summary: A very nice and simple way to use hardened Firefox

description: The performance is very good and most advanced settings can easly be changed.

i like all the features it offers and such but my only issue is it's not for mobile devices so i will just stick with normal firefox but it's still pretty good if you don't care if it has a mobile app
Preconfigured Firefox fork with all the junk settings removed. Just add some additional uBlock Origin filters and you are good to go. Highly reccomend!
The defaults for privacy and security are a great plus to the overall experience of firefox as a browser.

Firefox is great, but it takes quite a lot of setting adjustments and extensions to remove the junk and make it truly respect your privacy. LibreWolf, on the other hand, properly sets dozens of privacy-respecting default settings right from the beginning. If you're setting up multiple computers or distro-hopping then LibreWolf is an invaluble time-saver, and it also provides the ease of mind of knowing that you didn't forget to set one of the many settings necessary for maximum privacy.

I've been using LibreWolf for roughly six months. I'm an advanced Linux user. I find the product barely usable. There are constant battles to get camera, mic and sound working.
I understand that there are sacrificies to be made in terms of comfort in order to get security and privacy priority, but it seems to me, that the balance has not been found. Despite my best and sincere efforts to get periphery devices working in the browser I still can't make them just work when I need to. Over the time I have built a sort-of mistrust to the product, because you can't never tell if it will be working, when it breaks, etc.
It's probable that the flatpak distribution contributed to Librewolf's many issues (flatpak does its own sandboxing / permissions layer to already quite extensive configuration).
A firefox fork tweaked with telemetry disable by default
I installed this after trying just about every other browser available for Linux and I'm glad to say that it is just what I need. Great job!

An updated no-telemetry firefox, probably the easiest way to get a better firefox. It's usable and do everything you expect out of the box.
From a privacy standpoint, it's not the most you can get with firefox, another easy way is the arkenfox user.js project. If you compare both, arkenfox is more secure and as usable. 
Where librewolf really fails is against fingerprinting, its fingerprint is really peculiar and it's easy to figure out that you are using librewolf or at least something really weird that makes you unique.
It's a great candidate if you separate different parts of your life in different browsers.
Not worth it. Instead, I modified firefox' s "about:config" into hardened firefox and called it FireWolf.
This is a pretty good browser.
There seems to be no way to configure permission for external storage.

I am a longtime Firefox user. I only discovered LibreWolf last night. Love the project and the product so far. Key feature for me is the privacy expertise of the platform packaged into a product I can use pretty much out of the box:
* I left most of the settings as is
* I only imported bookmarks and setup couple extra extensions

Now I can run double browser setup with Firefox-based browsers only. 

I wanted to show the maintainers some love and support with 5 stars. This is not meant to be a comprehensive review.
aadwada dwad asf
If it gets a Privacy on/off button, it will be the next firefox in terms of popularity. Right now is the best privacy browser for us linux users.

Love this browser. Firefox without the privacy issues.
Only things I would like to see if Firefox Sync support, or alternatively a LibreWolf Android browser - that is downloaded and updated directly from LibreWolf's website (similar to Telegram).

Good work to the devs!

Pros:
- Firefox without telemetry
- Privacy OK

Cons:
- Sandboxed with all its drawbacks (for ex: can´t open specific URLs to trigger other applications)
summary: Firefox without telemetry, but feels unpolished

description: I've taken to using Librewolf instead of Firefox because it offers better privacy and it won't get converted into a snap by Canonical. I still keep Firefox around as a fallback, though.
Clean and minimal UI with ideal privacy defaults right out of the box.

description: I love the fact it removes all telemetry and it also makes a great effort to keep your privacy a priority, it may be a little bit difficult to adapt to things like all website data being deleted upon closing the browser, yet when you get used to it, you really learn to love its way to surf the web
I love this Firefox fork the best

Is this a major bruh moment in flatpak or LibreWolf? I checked Fedora flatpak firefox and the file access system works great so please fix this asap if you are possible.

description: Completely unresponsive on steam deck.
I don't know what the other SD reviewers are talking about, this is working great for me. Fast, responsive, and compatible with everything that hasn't gone out of its way to block Firefox.

I've been using Librewolf for several months now as my default browser, and its been rock solid. It's a Firefox fork that offers better privacy features.

You can go to: (https://privacytests.org/) and see for yourself how Librewolf compares to other browesers out there.

I don't think this browser gets the recognition that it deserves.
Firefox is really problematic in latest Fedora releases. Javascript not working properly, video not playing on most websites. Librewolf however works like a charm and is more private
Is Firefox, but better for privacy by default.

Simple, does its job, haven't seen a single ad nor annoying pop-up, haven't had a single issue (except for websites that use WebGL, but you can just turn it on anyway).

Everytime I try a new browser, I always just end up going back to Librewolf, 10/10 browser

I've been searching for a browser similar to Brave but based on Firefox, and while at first i've tried Mullvad Browser, it wasn't the right fit exactly. This one feels closer to Brave and well.. i don't need to change anything. Most stuff (besides DNS for me) was ready to go.
summary: Hardene Firefox from the get go

description: I recently downloaded this app and it has a lot of great features, no complaints yet but it's very annoying that it's not locking to the unity dock. I'm fairly certain I installed Ubuntu Unity 22.04.1, please fix this as soon as possible.
summary: It's not locking to the Unity 7.6 sidebar..

description: Excellent FF based browser ive just added to my Fedora Kinoite PC
Semi-hardened firefox straight from launch, you can still use preferences from Arkenfox ofc... but this browser is meant to make that process unnecessary by doing some of that for you!
the internet is extremely creepy today, luckily we have privacy browsers like this
Just as the title says, this browser is great for privacy and security. Love using it
Very private. Even better with ArkenFox user.js. My only problem is that I can't get the WindScribe proxy extension to work.

All of the functionality of Firefox without the tracking and telemtry with baked in added privacy features. 

Great OOTB experience. CSS theming ins't hampered whatsoever. My new home for the web.

For even more security I recommend adding "No Script" to better protect yourself from what lurks online.
I thought the privacy limitations would be annoying, but so far my experience has been quite epic. There is nothing to complain about besides some firefox bugs
I like the toggle for choosing to store cookies on every tab.
Getting used to not having cookies or a browsing history (unless enbled) takes a bit of time but it's something I gladly take for my privacy.

"GNOME Software" says this browser requires access to all contents of any open window (of literally any program). Could you please, clarify the reasoning behind this? Even the official vanilla "Mozilla Firefox", which is the base of LibreWolf, does not have this level of system access. However, "flathub.org" (the website) says nothing about these particular privileges. Is this just a bug in GNOME Software, showing false information or is there a separate "Flathub"-repository for each Distro? I use Ar.., ahem, I mean "openSUSE Aeon", btw. Other than the privacy concerns, the user experience is rather good.
summary: Why require spying on any window?

description:
In search for an alternative to Firefox 91 on wayland, which produces annoying freezes regularly even in software mode, i have found this gem of a more solid fork with many nice features. The LibreWolf version is 91.0.1 and it runs more stable than the FF versions 91.0.1-2 but still freezes sometimes.
In comparison tests i found out, that LibreWolf uses older versions of LLVM and mesa driver, which seem to help a bit in terms of stability alongside with further measurements by the LibreWolf Community. WebGL is deactivated though but suprisingly web videos play faster and more responsive.
I am using FF for many years now, but something seems to be messed up in the mozilla FF headquarters lately. Hopefully they manage to solve their issues.
summary: Very fast and responsive al Hamdu li Llah

description: Librewolf is a really amazing browser. It basically is a hardened Firefox without the telemetry in Firefox (which is opt out). But still it's great to have a browser that is configured to be more secure out of the box, so you don't have to do the hardening yourself.

Praktisch gleichwertig zum Firefox mit mehr Schwerpunkt auf Privatsphäre.	Empfehlenswert auch als Alternative zu Chrome und Opera oder als unabhängiger Zweitbrowser für Projekte die besser einen extra Browser bräuchten.

I did a comparison of Browser speeds on Fedora

https://cloudsync.uol.de/s/eanda5nW9tnAzAS

and the Fedora RPM (preinstalled), the official Mozilla binary and the Flatpak where the fastest. Librewolf was actually pretty slow, even compared to Firefox using Arkenfox. "Mercury", an ESR-based, not privacy-optimized "speed optimized" Version of Firefox had no speed advantages over the other Projects.

If you want to use a fast browser, that has 
- drag & drop
- native Messaging with other apps (KeepassXC, Plasma Integration etc.)
- best speed

you may want the native Firefox versions (RPM or DEB). But to make it secure, you need to add Arkenfox (github.com/arkenfox/user.js), I made a tool to make it less extreme (github.com/trytomakeyouprivate/Arkenfox-softening)

So advantages of this browser:
- Flatpak, easy isolation, runs on every system
- You can simply disable X11 and have it run on Wayland (this is extremely weird for the RPM, with MOZ_ENABLE_WAYLAND=1 not working and no about:config entry, unlike "widget.use-xdg-desktop-portal.*" for the native KDE Portal)
- It has community maintained hardening and GUI settings
- Very easy to install for everyone
- The settings dont have to be updated manually

Arkenfox updating currently doesnt work automatically at all. See my repo where I try to accomplish that, it will arrive upstream when ready.
summary: Very nice for people that don't want a manual setup

description:
Yiiiihaaaaaw!! Taking pants off, swinging it around!!

Perfomance is better than FF.
with optional Canvas-Blocker-Add-On, for me the BEST EVER.

siempre he usado firefox pero esto ... es lo mejor de lo mejor que he probado... para los que les gusta algo simple y con una privasidad mas que aceptable... mas que mejor... es lo ideal... es un muy muy buen proyecto alternativo a los mas conocidos browsser ... gracias al grupo de desarrolladores va por muy buen camino...
pero no puedo cambiar idioma, sale error de conexión plis, lo demás bien

Me encanto LibreWolf es rapido, eficaz y seguro. Sin embargo al tener un computador de bajos recursos, con poca ram, me parece excesivo lo que consume, incluso mas que Firefox con varias extenciones instaladas. No es usable teniendo otros programas abiertos pues el sistema en general queda demasiado lento.
summary: Me gusta, pero consume mucha ram

description: Un navegador muy versatil, basado en firefox y sin nada que envidar a aquellos basados en chromium. Lo que para mi lo hace de lo mejor son sus "prebuild features" de privacidad y seguridad, que hacen que sea mas comodo navegar por la web, otorgando una capa mas de privacidad y haciendo que no tengas que preocuparte tanto por la recoleccion de datos que muchas compañias hacen sobre sus usuarios.
Es Firefox, todo lo bueno de él. Sumando una configuración de privacidad bastante equilibrada. Está muy bien.
summary: Firefox con una buena configuración de privacidad

description: muy buena aplicacion
Excelente utilidad, muy simple y efectiva, elimina el historial y no permite rastreo.-
